bibl.title: Letter from Gustaf E. Lambert to Albert E. Truby, September 10, 1943

div1.p: Lambert recalls life at Military Hospital No. 1. He mentions Ames and Pinto, and comments on Truby's book.

div1.head: Letter from Gustaf E. Lambert to Albert E. Truby, September 10, 1943
div1.opener:
FROM GEN. ALBERT E. TRUBY
Sept 10th - 43 8009 Avalon
Ave.
Chicago
Ill.
Gen. Albert. E. Truby
Dear Sir
div1.p:
It has taken me a long time
to state my oppinion on the book
but I have been on the shelve and
couldn't write, now I'm alright
again I've made aquintance with
my 2 first patients in cuba the
young man from La Punty and
Col. O'Reilly. I was working in the
palace when Dr. Ames told me one
day to go home and prepare a bed
in the yellow fever dept. a young
man was sent there, I understand he
was a clerk in Gen. Brooks office
Dr Wells lost his commission on
account of that patient on the 4th day
Dr Ames had to report at pyrotecnia
Dr Wells took his place and was told
by Maj. Carter to stay in with the
patient, he came and looked in
the door and left, while not walking
around he met Maj. Carter, the Major
asked him (or told him) that his orders
were to stay with the patient Dr Wells
said he couldn't obey such orders as he
had to have fresh air Maj. Carter then told
him that if he couldn't obey orders he did
not belong in the army Dr Wells disappeared
from No 1 Dr Parrett took his place Dr
Parrett took a picture of the patient himself
and me I had hold of that picture only
a short time ago but can't find it now
it was unmounted and might be hid in
some book, there was only one bed in
the ward and the first three days and
nights I never closed my eyes the 3rd
night I was afraid to sit down
because I knew I would have fallen
asleep, at 2 A.M. Dr Ames found me
standing up against the door jam dead
asleep, he laid me down on the floor
and put a spare blanket under my head
and let me sleep to 7 A.M. I was
scared stiff when I woke up and saw
the Doctor sitting longside the bed, but he
told me it was alright he knew I
was tired out, from there on I was
Dr Ames's man friday because I felt that
if it had been some of the other
Doctors they might have had me carted
over to the gaurdhouse, on the 5th day
Dr Ames got a civilian a man from
New Orleans immune to come in
and help, but he was left alone next
day as I was sent over to Pyrotecnia
to take care of Col. O.Reilly who had his
quarters there but he did not have yellow
fever I understand Mrs Ames the
“widow” have a letter of thanks that
Col. O Reilly sent Dr Ames after he
got well, I was a little surprised that
it wasn't mentioned that Dr Ames
himself had yellow fever Maj. Stark
treated him and must have signed
his release from the hosp. I have Dr Ames's
service record from the Adj. Gen. Office
and it states that Dr. Ames had yellow
fever I'm a little dissapointed that the
book did not show Miss Lewis affidavit, that
Dr. Ames was carried during his own illness
down to the pest house to attend to Andrus
when Dr. Pinto was negligent in taking
care of him I got an awfull calling
down from Maj. Stark for taking Dr Ames
did and all down there, but his anger
was only temporary Maj. stark was very
kind to me later I was the last person
he operated on in quemados, he did
that after he was retained. I see that the
blue print map you sent me for inspec.
tion was used, of course no one knows
the difference but I lived down there
for over Six months and Dr Pinto was
not down there more than 6 or 8 times
(if that many) I still remembert the
old shacks well enough to point
out the leeks in the roof if they were
still standing. Book is good and as soon
as sold in chicago I will send one to
Miss Lewis who is living in Pasadena
and one to the Headquarters of the ladies
of the appalachian to show that they bestowed
their first Lady Honor on Mrs Warner for
work that I did and not she again I
thank you for the book
div1.closer:
Very Sincerely yours Gust E. Lambert over
AC
Io to L
Pardon the poor writing but
my vission is geting poorer every
day. Ive had to quit working and
my address is now 8009 Avalon ave
Zone
